Items.Title: Roll Call
Invocation
Items.AgendaNote:
Delivered by:  Rev. Craig Gaddy, Friendship Baptist Church, 92 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn, New York  11216.  

Motion to spread the invocation in full upon the record by COUNCIL MEMBER REYNA.
Items.MinutesNote:
The Invocation was delivered by Rev. Craig Gaddy, Friendship Baptist Church, 92 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11216.

Council Member Reyna moved  that the invocation be spread in full upon the Minutes and adopted.

Items.Title: Adoption of Minutes
Items.AgendaNote: Motion that the Minutes of the Stated Meeting of May 19, 2004 be adopted and printed by Council Member Nelson.
Items.MinutesNote: Council Member Nelson moved that the Minutes of the Stated Meeting of  May 19 , 2004 be adopted and printed

Items.Title: Messages & Papers from the Mayor
Items.MinutesNote: None.

Items.Title: Communications from City, County & Borough Offices
Items.MinutesNote: None.

Items.Title: Petitions and Communications
Items.MinutesNote: None.

Items.Title: Land Use Call-Ups

By Council Member Quinn:
Pursuant to Rule 11.20(b) of the Council and Section 20-226(g) of the New York City Administrative Code, the Council resolves that the action of the Department of Transportation approving an enclosed sidewalk café located at 645 Ninth Avenue, Borough of Manhattan, Council District no. 3, shall be subject to review by the Council. (Application no. 20045511 TCM.)
Items.MatterName: Sidewalk Cafe, 645 Ninth Avenue, Manhattan (20045511TCM)

Items.Title: Communication from the Speaker
Discussion of General Orders
Reports of Special Committees
Items.MinutesNote: None.

Items.Title: Reports of Standing Committees
Report of the Committee on Contracts
A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the provision of equal employment benefits to the employees of city contractors.
Items.MatterName: Equal employment benefits to the employees of city contractors.

Items.Title: Communication from the Mayor - Mayors veto and disapproval message of Introductory Number 137-B, in relation to the provision of equal employment benefits to the employees of city contractors.
Items.MatterName: Mayor's Veto, Int 137-B, Equal employment benefits to the employees of city contractors.

Items.Title: Resolution opposing President Bush’s FY 2005 budget proposal to drastically cut funding for the Section 8 Housing Choice Voucher program and replace it with block grants to local housing authorities and calling upon the Congress of the United States to reject this proposal.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MinutesNote: Adopted by voice vote.  The following 2 Council Members voted against the passage of this item: Council Members Gallagher and Lanza.
Items.MatterName: Opposing FY'05 budget proposal to drastically cut funding for the Section 8 Housing Choice Voucher program.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development to create and implement policies that provide greater transparency regarding the status of buildings whose Section 8 status is set to expire or which have been labeled “distressed” by the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
Items.AgendaNote: Adopted by the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MinutesNote: Adopted by voice vote.  The following Council Member abstained to vote on this matter:  Council Member Felder.
Items.MatterName: US Dep't of Housing and Urban Development to create and implement policies that provide greater transparency regarding the status of buildings whose Section 8 status is set to expire or which have been labeled "distressed".

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon President Bush and the United States Congress to eliminate the shortfall in funding for Section 8 Housing Choice Vouchers and to restore full funding for Fiscal Year 2004.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MinutesNote: Adopted unanimously by voice vote.
Items.MatterName: Eliminate the shortfall in funding for Section 8 Housing Choice Vouchers.

Items.Title: Report of the Committee on Immigration
A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to immigration assistance services.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Approved by Council
Items.MatterName: Immigration assistance services.

Items.Title: General Orders Calendar
Commissioner of Deeds
Items.MatterName: Commissioner of Deeds

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of health and mental hygiene to track and report deaths of homeless persons in the city of New York.
Items.MatterName: DOHMH to track and report deaths of homeless persons in NYC.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to prohibiting the use of racial or ethnic profiling by law enforcement officers.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Approved by Council
Items.MatterName: Prohibit the use of racial or ethnic profiling by members of the Police Dept.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to adopt A.5796-A and S.4805, which would legalize the possession, manufacture, sale, administration, delivery, dispensing and distribution of marijuana in connection with medical use for certified patients.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Health
Items.MinutesNote: Adopted by voice vote.  The following 4 Council Members voted against the passage of this item: Council Members Gallagher, Gentile, Jennings and Vallone Jr.
Items.MatterName: Legalize marijuana in connection with medical use for certified patients. (A.5796/S.4805)

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to prohibiting acts of harassment at schools.
Items.MatterName: Prohibiting acts of harassment at schools.

Items.Title: Resolution rejecting the Mayor’s ill-conceived educational policy of retaining third graders in New York City public schools based upon their scores on the English language and mathematics standardized examinations, by which time it is too late to begin intervention for struggling students, and which policy offers those students too little support.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Education
Items.MinutesNote: Adopted by voice vote. The following 10 Council Members formally objected to the passage of this item: Council Members Addabbo, Avella, Felder, Fidler, Lanza, Provenzano, Vallone Jr., Yassky and Oddo.
Items.MatterName: Renouncing DOE on their proposed policy to deny third graders in NYC public schools promotion to the fourth grade solely on the basis of their scores on the English Language Arts and Mathematics standardized exams.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring that the New York city department of education provide voter registration forms to students.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Approved by Council
Items.MatterName: Dep't of education of the city of New York provide voter registration forms to students.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York in relation to flammables and combustibles and penalties recoverable in proceedings before the environmental control board, and to repeal subdivision c of section 27-4065, subdivision b of section 27-4069, and subdivisions a, b and c of section 27-4070, to repeal and reenact subdivisions 10 and 22 of section 27-4002, sections 27-4015, 27-4063, 27-4064, 27-4066, 27-4067, 27-4068 and 27-4070 of such code.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Approved by Council
Items.MatterName: In relation to flammables and combustibles.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to mechanical refrigeration and to repeal  subchapter 18 of chapter 4 of title 27 relating to mechanical refrigeration.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Approved by Council
Items.MatterName: In relation to mechanical refrigeration.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to awnings.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Approved by Council
Items.MatterName: In relation to awnings.

Items.Title: Resolution offering the Council’s full support for the “Invisible No More!” campaign that is dedicated to winning home health aide contracts that mandate a Living Wage of $10 an hour by 2006, health benefits for home health aides and their families, paid vacation time and sick leave.
Items.AgendaNote: Adopted by the Committee on Health
Items.MinutesNote: Adopted by voice vote.  The following Council Member objected against the passage of this item: Council Member Lanza.  The following Council Member abstained to vote on this matter: Council Member Oddo.
Items.MatterName: Offering the Council's full support for the "Invisible No More" campaign.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to newsracks.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Approved by Council
Items.MatterName: In relation to newsracks.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon government officials to protect and uphold First Amendment rights to freedom of speech, association and assembly.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Governmental Operations
Items.MinutesNote: Adopted by voice vote.  The following 5 Council Members objected against the passage of this item: Council Members Gallagher, Gentile, Lanza, Provenzano and Oddo.
Items.MatterName: Government officials to protect and uphold First Amendment rights to freedom of speech, association and assembly.

Items.Title:
Introduction & Reading of Bills
See Attached
General Discussion
Extension of Remarks
INTRODUCTION AND READING OF BILLS

A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring notification to community boards and council members of applications for issuance of alteration permits for cellular telephone antennas and equipment.
Items.MatterName: Notification to community boards and council members of applications for issuance of alteration permits for cellular telephone antennas and equipment.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to making it a misdemeanor to use a city agency or service to harass another person or entity.
Items.MatterName: Making it a misdemeanor to use a city agency or service to harass another person or entity.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring electrical conductors and utility service lines in Queens county to be placed underground.
Items.MatterName: Requiring electrical conductors and utility service lines in Queens county to be placed underground.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to idling restrictions pertaining to school buses and reporting requirements.
Items.MatterName: Idling restrictions pertaining to school buses and reporting requirements.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the appropriate committee of the Council to conduct an oversight hearing on New York City’s insufficient enforcement of New York State Public Health Law 1310, relating to the removal of canine waste in cities.
Items.MatterName: Insufficient enforcement of NYS Public Health Law 1310, relating to removal of canine waste.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to banning the sale of certain substances containing lead.
Items.MatterName: Banning the sale of certain substances containing lead.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the noise control code and the repeal of subchapters 4, 5 and 6 of chapter 2 of title 24 of such code.
Items.MatterName: In relation to the noise control code

Items.Title: Resolution calling on President George Bush, the U.S. Congress and the U.S. Department of Defense to overturn the current “Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell, Don’t Pursue” policy and allow lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgendered persons to serve openly in the military.
Items.MatterName: Overturn the "Don't Ask, Don't Tell, Don't Pursue" policy and allow lesbians and gays to serve openly in the military.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Department of Health and Human Services to create a comprehensive database that would be available to the public in which all clinical drug trials performed in the United States could be registered, and to require all pharmaceutical companies to register all studies, whether published or not, with the database.
Items.MatterName: Require that pharmaceutical companies make all unpublished studies accessible to the public.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the United States Congress to pass legislation protecting computer and Internet users from privacy violations and security violations created and exploited by spyware.
Items.MatterName: Protecting computer and Internet users from privacy violations and security violations created and exploited by spyware.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to pass Assembly bill A.07463 and Senate bill S.6670-A, a companion measure, sponsored by Assemblyman Brian McLaughlin and Senator Serphin Maltese, respectively, to assist public sector attorneys with the repayment of their student loans, and calling upon the State Legislature to provide and distribute the requisite funds to comply with the terms of the “Legal Services Assistance Fund.”
Items.MatterName: Legal Services Assistance Fund

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to standards and specifications for accessible water borne commuter services facilities for disabled persons in New York City.
Items.AgendaNote: Mental Health, Mental Retardation, Alcoholism, Drug Abuse & Disability Services and Transportation
Items.MatterName: Standards and specifications for accessible facilities and passenger ferry water borne transportation services for disabled individuals in NYC.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter, in relation to requiring the department of information technology and telecommunications to keep records of all calls received through the 311 Citizen Service Center hotline regarding reports of electrical shocks occurring on City streets or sidewalks, including calls reporting locations believed to pose a risk of electrical shock, and to require that the department submit to the council and make available on the city’s official website, bi-annual reports documenting such data.
Items.MatterName: Keep records of all calls received through the 311 Citizen Service Center hotline.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Council of the City of New York to support the Albany County Supreme Court petition of Elissa Kane and Lynne Lekakis and Robert Barnes and George Jurgsatis seeking to compel the State Department of Health to permit the Albany County City Clerk to issue marriage licenses to the two couples who were recently joined by a Unitarian Universalist Minister.
Items.MatterName: Permit the Albany County City Clerk to issue marriage licenses to the two couples who were recently joined by a Unitarian Universalist Minister.

Items.Title: Resolution urging Governor Pataki and the New York State Office of Mental Health to request that the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) reopen the Project Liberty Program, which provided counseling to individuals, families and groups who were seriously traumatized by the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks in New York City.
Items.AgendaNote: Mental Health, Mental Retardation, Alcoholism, Drug Abuse & Disability Services
Items.MatterName: Request an extension of the project Liberty Program.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the City of New York to advance the percentage of clean natural gas-fueled vehicles in its fleet and to place particular emphasis on replacing medium- and heavy-duty vehicles with clean natural gas-fueled vehicles; to pursue public-private partnerships and grants and other incentives from federal, state and local agencies for the acquisition and deployment of clean alternative fuel vehicles and infrastructure; and, to promote the operation of clean natural gas-fueled taxi cabs in New York City.
Items.MatterName: Advance the percentage of clean natural gas-fueled vehicles in its fleet .

Items.Title: Resolution declaring September to be "Blood and Bone Marrow Donor Month" in the City of New York.
Items.MatterName: September to be "Blood and Bone Marrow Donor Month" in NYC.

Items.Title: State Legislation Resolution requesting the New York State Legislature to pass bills introduced by Senator Dilan, S.7233-A, and Committee on Rules, A.11069-A, “AN ACT to authorize the city of New York to discontinue the use of certain lands as park lands”.
Items.MatterName: Discontinue the use of certain lands as park lands (S.7233-A, A.11069-A)

Items.Title: Resolution urging the United States Senate to adopt S.3103 and the United States Congress to adopt H.R.5632, which would amend the Communications Act of 1934 to clarify and reaffirm state and local authority to regulate the placement, construction and modification of broadcast transmission facilities.
Items.MatterName: Regulate the placement, construction and modification of broadcast transmission facilities.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the United States Senate to approve additional federal funding for cities at the greatest risk of terrorist attack, and calling on the US House of Representatives to reconsider its vote on rejecting such a proposal.
Items.MatterName: Approve additional federal funding for cities at the greatest risk of terrorist attack.

Items.Title: A Local Law in relation to the renaming of Fulton street, Borough of Brooklyn, so that it shall hereafter be known as Harriet Ross Tubman Avenue and to amending the official map of the City of New York accordingly.
Items.MatterName: Name Change, Harriet Ross Tubman Avenue, Brooklyn

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to imposing a housing requirement for victims of domestic violence.
Items.MatterName: Imposing a housing requirement for victims of domestic violence.

Items.Title: Application no. 20045679 TCM pursuant to §20-226 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, concerning a modification to the petition of 7th & Barrow LLC, d/b/a Sushi Samba 7, to continue maintain and operate an unenclosed sidewalk café located at 87 7th Avenue South, Borough of Manhattan, Council District no. 3.  This application is subject to review and action by the Land Use Committee only if called-up by vote of the Council pursuant to Rule 11.20b of the Council and §20-226(g) of the New York City Administrative Code.
Items.MatterName: Sidewalk Cafe, 87 7th Avenue South, Manhattan (20045679TCM)

Items.Title: Application no. 20045511 TCM, pursuant to §20-226 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, concerning the petition of Zanzibar LLC, to continue maintain and operate an unenclosed sidewalk café located at 645 Ninth Avenue, Borough of Manhattan, Council District no. 4.  This application is subject to review and action by the Land Use Committee only if called-up by vote of the Council pursuant to Rule 11.20b of the Council and §20-226(g) of the New York City Administrative Code.
Items.MatterName: Sidewalk Cafe, 645 Ninth Avenue, Manhattan (20045511TCM)

Items.Title: Roll Call

By Council Member Quinn:
Pursuant to Rule 11.20(b) of the Council and Section 20-226(g) of the New York City Administrative Code, the Council resolves that the action of the Department of Transportation approving an enclosed sidewalk café located at 87 7th Avenue South, Borough of Manhattan, Council District no. 3, shall be subject to review by the Council. (Application no. 20045679 TCM.)
Items.MatterName: Sidewalk Cafe, 87 7th Avenue South, Manhattan (20045679TCM)

Items.Title: Roll Call

Resolutions

VICTOR L. ROBLES, City Clerk
